#Text=Morelia
#Text=With a consistent colonial-style throughout , Morelia is one of the most beautiful cities in Mexico .
#Text=It is not really on the well-trodden path of the leisure tourists and so you can walk around in comfort without fear of the bermuda shorts crowds .
#Text=Morelia is the capital of the state of Michoacan in Mexico and it is a registered UNESCO World Heritage site .
#Text=There are at least two " information " booths in the area of the square .
#Text=They are staffed with multilingual students who are very helpful .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Morelia is the capital city of Michoacan .
#Text=It serves government and many students attending school there .
#Text=The central business district is very clean with plenty of places to eat and shop .
#Text=Tourists are not as common here as some other areas of Mexico .
#Text=You may want to load up on pesos before ordering food or trying to make a purchase , as foreign currency is not widely accepted .
#Text=There are money changer stalls on the side streets off of the square .
#Text=It has a decent climate , nice parks to relax in , lots of places to get stuff , and very nice place over all .
#Text=If you stay downtown , most of the attractions like the Cathedral , the square , museums , and shopping , are all pretty much within walking distance .
#Text=Due to Morelia 's location , being a college town and center of State Government , tourist are not as common as some other areas of Mexico .
#Text=The People are very friendly .
#Text=In the central business district , drivers use their horns 24 hours a day to excess , prodding other drivers and to give notice at the numerous blind intersections .
#Text=You will get used to it , but request a room away from the street .
#Text=Morelia is more than just the downtown .
#Text=Its outlying areas feature modern housing developments , shopping centers and parks .
#Text=Tres Marias and Altozano are ultra-modern newest residential areas .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Deluxe buses serve Morelia from all parts of the Republic , and Morelia 's state-of-the-art bus station , located in the northern part of the city .
#Text=The bus station consists of separate terminals for first-class and second-class buses .
#Text=Cost of taxi going to downtown from bus station is about 60 pesos ( Jan 2018 ) , you can buy a ticket from the kiosk inside the station and then give it to the taxi driver .
#Text=It is easy to reach Morelia from either Mexico City or Guadalajara .
#Text=The bus trip from Guadalajara is about 4 1/2 hours and from Mexico City is 4 hours , depending on the company .
#Text=You can also reach Morelia from the United States by way of Greyhound .
#Text=By car
#Text=Morelia is accessible by a modern toll road , and is located equidistant from Guadalajara and Mexico City , is about 3 1/2 hours driving .
#Text=There are plenty of gas stations along the way with restrooms and food .
#Text=Be prepared with change/pesos to pay tolls
#Text=the cost may vary depending of the route you take , from Mexico City is about M$ 500 ( pesos ) one way .
#Text=It is a very scenic trip , to say the least .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Morelia International Airport ( MLM General Francisco Mujica International Airport ) .
#Text=Relatively new , modern airport at the edge of town .
#Text=There are daily international flights from LAX , IAH and ORD and scheduled flights from SFO , SJC , as well as commuter flights from GDL , MEX , BJX and TIJ .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Buses , combis and taxis form Morelia ’s public transport .
#Text=Combis are a good way to see the smaller roads and backstreets of the city .
#Text=Various destinations are usually indicated on the windshield of these mini-vans .
#Text=As of November 2011 , a ride within the city costs 6 pesos .

#Text=Get in , grab a handle and sit down before the driver speeds off , and then give your money directly to the driver , or to someone else to pass to the driver for you ( you can ask the person “ Si no le molesta , por favor ” , basically , “ thanks , if you do n’t mind ” ) .
#Text=Above your head you will find a buzzer to get out at the next corner , or you can simply ask “ en la próxima ezquina , por favor ” ( next corner please ) .
#Text=It is very common for people to greet other passengers when boarding , according to the time of day ( “ Buenos días ” , “ buenas tardes ” or “ buenas noches ” ) .
#Text=Taxis are also plentiful and inexpensive , operating on zone fares .
#Text=As elsewhere in Mexico , make sure to determine the price before getting into the taxi .
#Text=Driving in the city is not easy , but with patience you can .
#Text=Drivers use their horns to excess , to prod others and at the numerous blind intersections .
#Text=The Centro Histórico is plagued by lack of parking .
#Text=Driving in and around Morelia differs little from driving in any urban area .
#Text=However , there is an “ uno y uno ” protocol in place .

#Text=Drivers are actually quite respectful and obey this “ one and one ” rule , where — in stark contrast to Mexico City — at an intersection , you do not simply charge into any space larger than 5 cm , but fall into line , with one vehicle at a time from each direction driving through the intersection .
#Text=See
#Text=There are a lot of interesting and beautiful colonial buildings to see in Morelia , most of them are open to the public for at least part of the day .
#Text=Highlights of a Morelia city tour will include :
#Text=Cathedral : One of the downtown highlights is the baroque cathedral with its surrounding gardens and parks .
#Text=The cathedral is enormous , covering more than 2 city blocks in area .
#Text=Architectural details like the flying buttresses and tiled cupolas give it a distinctive look .
#Text=The Cathedral is the site for the local “ Day of the Dead ” celebration in early November .
#Text=It is more of an experience than can be described here .
#Text=Most of the activities take place after dark , make sure you have a good seat around the square at dark for the outside performance of the choir and the fireworks each night .
#Text=Casa Natal de Morelos and Casa de Morelos : Hero of the Mexican War for Independence , native son Jose Maria Morelos y Pavon , was born , raised , and lived his life in Morelia .
#Text=There are two Morelos homes in the city , and both are historical museums that chronicle Morelos and his role in shaping Mexico .
#Text=Aqueduct :
#Text=Running down the center of Avenida Acueducto is an enormous aqueduct built in the 17th century to bring water into the budding young city .
#Text=Santuario de Guadalupe : One of the most serenely beautiful churches in Mexico , adorned in soft pink and white with gold trim , the church is a work of art in itself .
#Text=It also houses a series of 17th century oil paintings that ideologically depict the Spanish missionaries ’ conquest over the “ barbaric ” religious traditions of the Aztecs .

#Text=Benito Juarez Zoological Park is a 250-ha ( 620-acre ) urban oasis that is home to a 30-m ( 75-acre ) lake and a large and diverse collection of animals , including everything from polar bears to monkeys .
#Text=Kids love it !
#Text=Admission costs M$ 12 for adults and $ 6 for kids .
#Text=Open 7 days a week .
